We have found that a similar feature=
 in DevCreek has turned out to be
quite useful. We have a simple alert in o=
ur Eclipse plug-in that can
warn you if you haven't run a test within a con=
figured amount of time.
  We also have a graphic representation of the last=
 few hours of
testing activity. So you can see when you last ran a test, ho=
w long
you have been fixing a test, and an impression of your recent testin=
g
rhythm.

For screen shots of the test run ticker:
https://community.devcr=
eek.com/space/David+Jones/blog/2007-03-26_1

And you can see the website vi=
ew based on actual testing:
https://devcreek.com/principalActivity/TestCree=
k/DGJ

The alerts in combination with the graphics activity summary do seem=

to be useful for both guiding the adoption of a TDD style, and also
for hi=
ghlighting to the more experienced tester when they have drifted
from their=
 preferred style such as when one gets lost in the debugger
for hours rathe=
r than writing a new test.

One feature that we have talked about about imp=
lementing in the past,
would be to publish these graphics traces of testing=
 activity rhythms
for beginners to use then as exemplars to work towards. P=
erhaps even
some silly scoring mechanism to rate how close you measure to y=
our
favourite star tester.

Another direction could be for the expert exper=
imenting with altering
their testing and development practices to collect a=
 series of
recorded traces as one record and measure of their exploration a=
s they
weigh up the pros/cons of the variations they have tried.


Cheers
D=
avid Jones
